name: Portrait Of An Artist: Sargent Multiple Choice Quiz | People | 10 Questions

questions.text: For what type of painting was Sargent chiefly known?
questions.explanation:
portraits.

	Sargent is considered by many to be the greatest American portraitist in history.

questions.text: Sargent was an American, but he was born in Europe. In what well-known art mecca did he come into the world?
questions.explanation:
Florence.

	Although his parents were from the U.S., Sargent lived most of his life in Europe.

questions.text: Sargent's virtuoso style was reminiscent of that of the old Spanish masters. Which of the following painters served as an influence?
questions.explanation:
Velazquez.

	Some people refer to the 'Spanishness' of Sargent's portraits. This is largely due to the profound influence of the Spanish artist Diego Velazquez on his works.

questions.text: Sargent settled and studied under his teacher Carolus-Duran from 1874 to 1876. To what city did he come for his art education?
questions.explanation:
Paris.

	During this time (late 19th century) Paris was the center of the art world, so naturally it would make sense for Sargent to have come there.

questions.text: In 1884, he became famous in Paris for a scandal started after the exhibition of a certain portrait called 'Madame X'. Who was the subject of this portrait?
questions.explanation:
Madame Gautreau.

	The portrait was exhibited at the Paris Salon as 'Madame X' to protect the anonymity of the sitter. It didn't work.

questions.text: What was it about the portrait of 'Madame X' that aroused such scandal?
options: It was actually a portrait of a man in drag.
It was painted in the impressionist style.
It was really a crappy painting.
questions.explanation:
It was seen as 'provocatively erotic'.

	The mother of the sitter was embarassed at the unwanted attention the portrait aroused in her daughter and condemned it, fueling the scandal. If you look at the painting itself you will be baffled by the idea that it was considered scandalous. People were disturbed by the slightly low-cut dress and the fact that one of the straps slips slightly off of one of Madame Gautreau's shoulder. Today, she'd be considered a prude.

questions.text: After being 'forced' out of Paris, where did he settle to continue his prolific career?
questions.explanation:
London.

	Sargent spent most of the rest of his life in London, enjoying his many poet and artist friends.

questions.text: Later in Sargent's career, he grew tired of portrait painting. He referred to portraiture as the profession of a what?
questions.explanation:
pimp.

	Sargent tried other styles late in his career but with much less success.

questions.text: Although disdaining his specialty, Sargent continued to do portraiture and painted portraits for many famous people. Which of the following was not a subject of his painting?
questions.explanation:
Pablo Picasso.

	For artists, making a living often places them in the perplexing position of having to accept commissions for that work which they most disdain.  After 1907 Sargent rarely took commissions...apparently he was comfortable enough to do so.

questions.text: Sargent was once described as 'an American born in Italy, educated in France, who looks like a _______, speaks like an Englishman and paints like a spaniard.' What goes in the blank?
questions.explanation:
German.

	This is a quote from the author William Starkweather who wrote 'The Art of John Singer Sargent'.  Thank you for having played the quiz...I hope you were able to learn a thing or two about this great portrait artist.
